Construction of hierarchical core-shell Pt/USY@MSA bifunctional catalysts for hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane Bo Wang Methodology Investigation Project administration Writing – original draft Jinsheng Zhao Project administration Supervision ⁎ Hongxi Pan Formal analysis Yunyun Dong Investigation Xiaolei Li Investigation Shuo Tao Conceptualization Supervision Project administration Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Energy Storage and Novel Cell Technology, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng, Shandong 252059, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Energy Storage and Novel Cell Technology, Liaocheng University Liaocheng Shandong 252059 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Energy Storage and Novel Cell Technology, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng, Shandong 252059, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes is an indispensable process in the upgrading of fuel oil and lubricants to meet the state of art regulations. In this work, a novel core-shell structural material comprising USY zeolite core and mesoporous aluminosilicate (MSA) shell, denoted as USY@MSA, was fabricated by virtue of a desilication and recrystallization approach. Comprehensive characterizations demonstrate that the USY@MSA composite exhibits a hierarchical pore architecture and a gradient acidity. Due to the confinement effect of the mesoporous aluminosilicate shell, highly dispersed platinum particles were selectively deposited on the shell, generating a nanoscale distance with acidic sites of USY zeolite core. In the hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane, the Pt/USY@MSA composite catalyst outperforms the conventional Pt/USY and desilicated Pt/USY-ds catalysts, effectively suppressing the cracking side reactions and producing higher selectivity to branched isomers. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Core-shell Hierarchical Nanoscale distance Hydroisomerization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the rising stringent environmental regulations, it is urgent to improve the quality of transportation oil to meet the environment and energy requirements. Typically, as an effective process for refining and upgrading of hydrocarbons, hydroisomerization of long-chain alkanes is widely employed in petroleum industry, Fischer-Tropsch reaction and vegetable oil transformation [1,2]. Compared to long-chain n-paraffins, the isomerized branched paraffins exhibits more favorable low-temperature properties, i.e. lower pour point and higher viscosity index [3,4]. However, owing to the similar activation energy, hydroisomerization of long-chain alkanes is always accompanied with cracking side reaction, and in consequence leads to poor isomer yields [5]. Accordingly, it is still facing a challenge to suppress cracking reactions and improve selectivity of branched molecules. Generally, the hydroisomerization of n-alkanes takes place over bifunctional catalyst containing both metal sites and acid sites. The formation of carbonium ions and skeletal rearrangement mainly occurs over acidic supports, such as amorphous oxide, zeolites and mesoporous materials [6,7]. As known to all, zeolites with unique shape-selectivity and adjustable acidity are the potential candidates as acidic supports for industrial application [8,9]. According to the well-acknowledged pore-mouth model and key-lock mechanism [10], one-dimensional 10-membered ring zeolites (i.e. ZSM-22, ZSM-48, ZSM-23, SAPO-11, SAPO-31) possess the similar pore size with the linear chain alkanes, and they are supposed to be the most promising acidic carriers in the hydroisomerization of alkanes [11]. By contrast, zeolites with larger pore size (such as Y and Beta) have shown inferior tendency towards branched molecules due to the cracking side reaction [12,13]. However, with respect to the long-chain alkanes, the confined spatial effect generated by the narrow one-dimensional 10-membered ring channel impose significant diffusion limitation and promote the cleavage of C-C bond. In this regard, multiple studies associated with the design of zeolites with hierarchical architecture were reported [14–18]. Particularly, alkaline-assisted post-treatment strategy was the most extensively studied to create mesopores into zeolites chanel [14]. Microporous and mesoporous structural SAPO-11 [15], ZSM-48 [16], ZSM-22 [17], and ZSM-12 [18] zeolites were constructed successively. It demonstrates that the hierarchical pore structure not only shortens diffusion path exhibiting excellent diffusivity, but also adjusts the accessibility of acidity. Hence the hierarchical architecture significantly enhances the branched isomer selectivity during long-chain alkane isomerization [19,20]. For the other hand, the metal components mainly catalyze the dehydrogenation of n-alkanes to the corresponding n-alkenes and the hydrogenation of i-alkenes to i-alkanes [21]. Platinum (Pt) specie has been the most widely used metal active site. Recent studies have found the mutual intimacy of Pt active site and acid sites is critical for gaining well balance between the two active sites and generating vital influence on isomerization performance [22]. Noteworthy is the results reported by de Jong’s group, which investigated the isomerization performance over the Pt-A/Y and Pt-Y/A bifunctional catalysts. The former is prepared by supporting Pt selectively on γ-alumina binder generating the nano-scaled intimacy, while the latter was prepared by supporting Pt selectively on Y zeolite forming the closet intimacy. Higher isomerization selectivity and lower cracking selectivity were obtained over Pt-A/Y catalyst [23,24]. In contrast, the alkene intermediates formed on metal sites have to diffuse across the Y zeolite channel over Pt-Y/A catalyst, which significantly increased the probability of cracking. Afterwards, Moussa and Samad et al. came to the similar conclusion that supporting Pt catalyst with nanometer scale intimacy contributes to the dominated branched isomers compared with the spatial arrangement of proximity or micrometric scale [25,26]. Most recently, K. Cheng et al. found the less platinum amount and higher isomer yield could be obtained when Pt particles selectively supported on the out surface of zeolite or alumina binder due to the well balance between two active sites [27]. These findings basically reveled that a nanoscale distance between the acid and metal sites was beneficial for isomerization reactions, which were in sharp contrast to the previous acknowledgment of “the close the better” principle proposed by Weisz and Batalha et al. [28,29]. Accordingly, in order to fabricate the outperformed bifunctional catalyst, the main challenge lies in how to organize the acidic carriers and metal components rationally to maximum the synergistic effect without disturbing the diffusion of reactant molecules. The construction of core-shell structural zeolites is an efficient route to control the location of supported metal particles. For example, hierarchical core-shell mesoporous aluminosilicate-coated zeolites (ZSM-5, SSZ-13, Beta) have been fabricated to selectively deposit metal on the mesoporous shell [30–32]. Herein, we fabricated a Pt-supported hierarchical core-shell catalyst via a controlled desilication and recrystallization route, through which the dissolved species were further utilized during the post-treatment process and formed the mesoporous shell coating on USY zeolites. For one hand, this material featured hierarchical pore structure and gradient acidity, facilitating the diffusion of reactants and products. For the other hand, the supported Pt particles were highly dispersed and selectively deposited on the mesoporous shell, keeping in nanoscale distance with acidic sites within USY zeolite. The combined effect may contribute to the superior branched isomers yield during the n-C16 hydroisomerization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of USY@MSA composites Pristine USY zeolite was purchased from Wenzhou Huahua Co., Ltd. USY@MSA composites were prepared via the controlled desilication process and recrystallization with triblock copolymer P123 (polyethylene-polypropylene glycol) as template. In a typical synthesis, pristine USY zeolite powders (1 g) were dissolved in 0.1 M NaOH solution (50 ml) containing desirable amount of piperidine (PI, PI/SiO2 molar ratio was 0.1) as structural protective agent. The mixture was sealed and heated at 65 °C for 30 min. Afterwards, 130 g H2O, 76 g ethanol and 2 g P123 were added into above mixture under continuous stirring. Subsequently, certain amount of 0.5 M HCl solution was dropped into above solution until the pH value reached close to 5.7. The solution was ultrasonicated for 30 mins to form homogeneous suspension. The suspension was firstly placed in water bath at 30 °C for 48 h and then heated to 75 °C reacting for another 24 h. After reaction, the white precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with deionized water and ethanol successively, and dried at 100 °C overnight. Finally, the sample, denoted as USY@MSA, was obtained after calcination at 550 °C for 5 h to remove organic template. For the control experiment, USY-ds samples were prepared through the identical desilication procedure. While MSA sample was obtained by following the above recrystallization procedures after removing undissolved bulky USY crystals. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The bifunctional catalysts of 0.50 wt% Pt-loaded zeolites were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method with H2PtCl6 as precursor. The zeolites were firstly placed into aqueous H2PtCl6 solution at 25 °C for 12 h, and evaporated to remove moisture. After drying at 120 °C for 4 h, the mixture was pressed and crushed into particles with size between 20 and 40 mess. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was collected on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 35 kV and 25 mA. The morphology of samples was determined by taking scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images with a Hitachi S-4800 microscopy. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained by using Tecnai G2 F30 microscope. N2 adsorption-desorption isothermal were performed on an BELSORP-MAX system by using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Prior to the test, the sample was outgassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 5 h. Total pore volume was calculated by the adsorbed amount at relative pressure P/P0 of 0.99. The micropore volume and size distribution of mesopores were determined by t-plot method and Battet-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. The 29Si and 27Al MAS NMR spectra were measured on a VARIAN VNMRS 400WB NMR spectrometer. The former was conducted at a frequency of 79.3 MHz with the spinning rate of 3 kHz. And the latter was conducted at a frequency of 104.2 MHz with the spinning rate of 10 kHz. The bulk chemical composition was determined by inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry (ICP) with a Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP atomic emission spectrometer. While the chemical composition on the surface were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected with a ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was performed on Micromeritica Auto Chem 2920. The samples were firstly heated to 550 °C for 1 h in Ar flow. After cooling down to 100 °C, NH3 was introduced to the system for 20 min. Then the samples were heated to 550 °C and the TPD profiles were recorded correspondingly with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under Ar flow. CO pulse chemisorption was performed on the same apparatus. Prior to analysis, the samples were in-situ reduced in H2 flow (50 ml/min) at 400 °C for 2 h. Then, the system was flushed with a flowing He atmosphere (50 ml/min) at 450 °C for 1 h. After cooling down to 50 °C, the CO pulses was passed through the samples until the effluent areas of consecutives pulses were constant. The Pt dispersion was calculated with the stoichiometry of CO/Pt= 1. The FT-IR spectra in hydroxyl stretching region and pyridine-adsorption FT-IR spectra were both collected on a Nicolet Nexus 670 FT-IR spectrometer in absorbance mode at a resolution of 2 cm−1. The sample was firstly pressed into a self-supported wafer and evacuated at 450 °C for 2 h. The FT-IR spectra in hydroxyl stretching region were recorded at the same time. As for the pyridine-adsorped FT-IR spectra, the samples were then exposed to pyridine vapor for 20 min after cooling down to ambient temperature. Afterwards, the adsorbed pyridine was evacuated by elevating the temperature to 450 °C for 1 h. 2.4 Catalytic experiments The hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane (n-C16) was conducted in a fixed-bed micro-reactor loaded with 2.0 g of the catalysts. The reaction conditions were 2.0 h−1 WHSV, 1.0 MPa, H2/n-C16 = 15 (molar ratio). Prior to reaction, the catalysts were reduced in situ in H2 flow at 400 °C for 4 h. Then the system was cooled down to the reaction temperature and n-C16 was then pumped to the reactor. The products were analyzed online by an Agilent 7890 gas chromatograph. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of the USY@MSA composite The preparation of USY@MSA composite included alkaline desilication and self-assembly processes. The pristine USY zeolite was firstly subjected to alkaline solution to remove framework Si atoms. The specific alkaline treatment conditions were firstly investigated comprehensively. Pristine USY shew typical and well-resolved Bragg diffractions attributed to the FAU topology ( Fig. 1a). The treatment in 0.1 M NaOH solution only led to complete collapse of zeolite framework, indicating USY zeolite couldn’t bear the harsh alkaline condition (Fig. S1A). Upon introduction of piperidine (PI), the peaks assigned to USY zeolite were well preserved, and the intensity basically increased as a function of piperidine amount added into the desilication system. The yields for different samples were calculated according to the grams of solids obtained after treatment compared with the pristine USY zeolite (Fig. S1B). As the ratio of PI/SiO2 increased from 0.02 to 0.6, the corresponding yield varied from 55% to 75%, implying the irreversible loss of framework elements upon desilication. Accordingly, piperidine molecule effectively protected the crystal structure against the attack of OH- and prevented the collapse of zeolite framework. To our best knowledge, TPA+ or TBA+ were frequently reported as protective agents in previous reports [33,34]. For example, Vu et al. constructed mesoporous Y zeolite by using octadecyltrimethylammonium hydroxide and bromide (C18TAOH/C18TABr) as surfactant recently [35]. Herein, the low cost and easily accessible piperidine acted as protecting agent substituted for the high priced tetraalkylammonium compounds. When the ratio of PI/SiO2 was 0.1, the corresponding yield was about 55%, where large proportion of Si species were dissolved and the framework structure of USY was preserved simultaneously (Fig. 1b). Hence, the mixture obtained at the above condition was then subjected to the subsequent self-assembly process. The peak intensity of USY@MSA sample further enhanced compared to the USY-ds sample, indicating the increased crystallinity upon self-assembly process (Fig. 1c). Then the pH value during self-assembly process was investigated in detail. As pH value increased from 1.7 to 7.1, the intensity of diffraction peaks gradually increased (Fig. S2A), while the corresponding yield firstly elevated to 91.2% and then decreased to 79.3% (Fig. S2B). The specific morphology of the samples treated at different pH values were investigated by SEM images. Pristine USY zeolite displays irregular bulk crystal with rough surface resulting from ultra-stable process ( Fig. 2a). Upon desilication treatment, numerous circular holes emerged on the surface due to the removal of Si species (Fig. 2b). When the pH value of self-assembly process kept at 1.7 and 2.5, the morphology of the samples was almost unchanged compared with USY-ds sample (Fig. 2c and d). With the pH value raised to 3.5, there were some tiny spheroidal particles dispersing around USY crystals (Fig. 2e). Until the pH value increased to 4.7, the angular USY zeolites were coated by a uniform shell with a spongy-like texture, presenting a smooth crystal edge (Fig. 2f). It presents the similar surface at the higher pH value of 5.7 and 6.2 (Fig. 2g and h). The above results indicate pH value plays an important role in the fabrication of core-shell material. Deep insight into the specific morphology of USY, USY-ds and USY@MSA samples were investigated by TEM technique. Pristine USY zeolite presents well-developed cross-shaped morphology and clearly lattice fringe ( Fig. 4a and b). Upon hydrothermal treatment, more mesopores were introduced into the USY-ds crystal (Fig. 4c and d). A typical core-shell structure consisting of alkaline-treated USY crystal and newly-formed shell was observed from TEM image of the USY@MSA sample. HRTEM image revealed a close connection between the shell and core, in which a disordered wormhole-like pore architecture grew connectedly on the surface of USY zeolite (Fig. 4e and f). To our best knowledge, SBA-15 mesoporous silica with highly ordered hexagonal channels could be fabricated by virtue of P123 template. It was inferred the dissolved species from the pristine USY zeolite assembled into the disordered lamellar mesoporous shell with the assistance of P123 template. Moreover, the shell thickness could be tuned from 20 nm to 60 nm by varying the alkaline treatment conditions (Fig. S3). And the corresponding yields calculated after self-assembly process reached up to 90%, indicating most of the dissolved silicon species were returned back to the composite (Fig. S4). Combined with the above characterizations, the core-shell structural USY@MSA sample can be fabricated through the desilication and self-assembly process. During alkaline desilication process, some Si atoms were removed from USY framework and dissolved in the system, acting as the nutrient of mesoporous silica shell. The oriental assembly of silicious species on the surface of USY core was critical during the self-assembly process, which was determined by the adsorption of the template micelle on the core surface. According to the previous reports, the isoelectric point (IEP) of siliceous oligomer was about 2, and the IEP of P123 micelles were about 6.2 [36]. The dissolution and polycondensation rates of silicon source were slow in strong acidic system, therefore it was difficult to form mesoporous silica phase, just as revealed in Fig. 2c. When pH value was between 2.5 and 3.5, the mesoporous silica sphere could be formed at this situation. But the interaction between P123 micelle and zeolite was weak leading to serious phase separation (Fig. 2d and e). The small silica grain was lapsed during centrifugation and washing processes, resulting to a low yield of 65% (Fig. S2B). When the pH value was controlled in the range of 4.7–6.2, P123 micelles were partially protonated and the zeolites were negatively charged, generating strong electrostatic attraction. The dissolved siliceous orientally assembled and formed mesoporous silica shell coating on the surface of zeolite crystal, resulting in a homogeneous core-shell structured USY@MSA material (Fig. 3). In this sense, the USY@MSA material described in the following experiments were all prepared at pH value of 5.7. The pore architecture of the samples was investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements ( Fig. 5). USY and USY-ds samples exhibited the similar type I (P/P0 <0.05) and IV (0.5 <P/P0 <1) isothermals, indicating the presence of both micropores and mesopores. While the isothermal of the USY@MSA sample presented an uptake at the pressure P/P0 < 0.6 (type I), type IV curves with H2 hysteresis loop at P/P0 of 0.6–0.85, and a third step at high pressure region (P/P0 = 0.8–1). The specific surface area (S BET), total pore volume (V tot) and mesopore volume (V meso) of USY zeolite were 752 m2 g−1, 0.54 cm3 g−1, and 0.3 cm3 g−1, respectively ( Table 1). Upon the desilication process in solution containing NaOH and piperidine, the S BET, V tot and V meso abruptly increased to 803 m2 g−1, 0.79 cm3 g−1, and 0.58 cm3 g−1, respectively. After coating the mesopore shell, the S BET was almost keep unchanged (799 m2 g−1), and the V tot and V meso were 0.71 cm3 g−1 and 0.54 cm3 g−1, respectively. Actually, the proportion of mesopore was highest among the three samples due to the internal desilication and the formation of mesoporous shell. As to the pore size distribution (Fig. 5B), USY and USY-ds samples exhibited a shoulder peak ranging from 20 to 30 nm, which was probably attributed to intra-crystal mesopores. By contrast, USY@MSA material showed a bimodal mesopore size distribution, including the intra-crystal mesopores around 40 nm and the mesopores resulting from the wormhole-like shell around 9 nm. Thus the core-shell USY@MSA material demonstrates a hierarchical structure and wider intra-crystal mesopores. The interconnected porosities characteristic was expected to make acid sites more accessible to reactants and facilitate the diffusion during catalytic reaction. To determine the variation of framework elements during alkaline-desilication and self-assembly processes, the elementary composition as well as the coordination state were investigated by various techniques. The initial bulk Si/Al molar ratio of pristine USY zeolite was 19, which significantly reduced to 12.7 after desilication treatment, indicating the leaching out of Si species from the crystal. Upon self-assembly process, the Si/Al molar ratio (20.7) raised close to the initial value, implying the dissolved Si or Al species returned back to the crystal. 27Al MAS NMR spectra of pristine USY zeolite consisted of two resonance peaks at 60 ppm and 0 ppm ( Fig. 6). The former peak is attributed to tetrahedrally coordinated alumina (AlIV) in the framework [37]. The latter one is indicative of extra-framework octahedral aluminum (AlVI) generated from the ultra-stable process, which is assigned to the Al(OH)6 3+ specie in highly asymmetrical environment [38]. Upon desilication treatment, the peak intensity at 0 ppm significantly reduced, while the peak at 60 ppm slightly increased conversely. Meanwhile the Si/Al molar ratio of MSA collected from the desiliconized solution was up to 233.1 (Table S1), manifesting extremely low amount of Al species contained in the mesoporous sample. Therefore, the desilication treatment mainly resulted in the dissolution of silicon species and partial extra-framework Al species. Upon self-assembly process, the signal at 0 ppm decreased further and the signal at 60 ppm kept almost unchanged. As can be seen from aforementioned results, the bulk Si/Al molar ratio and yield upon self-assembly process returned back to the initial level of pristine USY zeolite. We assumed that the dissolved octahedral Al species could be reinserted into the zeolite framework or mesoporous SiO2 shell. The above hypothesis was further verified by 29Si MAS NMR spectroscopy ( Fig. 7). All the samples exhibited one broad resonance band centered at about − 102.5 ppm. After deconvolution, the specific resonances at − 107, − 102, − 99, − 95 ppm were reasonably derived from Si(0Al), Si(1Al), Si(2Al), Si(3Al) building units, and the resonance at − 111 pm was generally attributed to the quartz phase [39]. After alkaline treatment, the percentage of Si(0Al) units decreased from 71.3% to 63.9%, whereas the proportion of Si(1Al) and Si(2Al) increased from 11.3% and 7.6–13.1% and 10.3%. It suggested that part of Si species leached out from zeolite framework leading to the reduction of Si(0Al) units and slight increase of Si(2Al) and Si(3Al) units. Upon self-assembly process, the proportion of Si(0Al) unit further decreased to 41.4%, and the proportion of Si(1Al) raised to 18.4%. However, the proportion belonging to Si(1Al) slightly decreased to 9.6%, accompanying with the appearance of new band at − 115 ppm, which was probably due to the formation of mesoporous SiO2 shell. Therefore, the extra-framework Al species within the crystal incorporated into the framework of mesoporous SiO2 shell during the desilication or self-assembly process, which was in good agreement with 27Al MAS NMR spectra. IR spectra in the region of hydroxyl stretching vibration were collected under vacuum conditions ( Fig. 8). With respect to pristine USY zeolite, the strong band at 3740 cm−1 was assigned to stretching vibration of isolated silanols (Si-OH) on the external surface [40], and the accompanying shoulder band at 3725 cm−1 was presumably associated with the hydrogen-bonded internal silanols [41]. The bands at 3622 cm−1 and 3560 cm−1 corresponded to Si(OH)Al hydroxyls within α cage and β cage in FAU topology structure [42]. By contrast, USY-ds sample exhibited a more intense band at 3740 cm−1 as well as weaken bands at 3560 cm−1 and 3622 cm−1, manifesting the substantial reduction of Si(OH)Al hydroxyls upon desilication treatment. Upon self-assembly process, the band at 3622 cm−1 slightly strengthened and presented left-shifts relative to the other two samples. The newly emerged Si(OH)Al hydroxyls may be correlated to the reinsertion of dissolved Al species into USY framework. To gain more insight into the acidity of the samples, we measured NH3-TPD profiles and pyridine-adsorption FT-IR spectra systemically. As shown in Fig. 9, NH3-TPD profiles of the pristine USY sample exhibited two peaks at 150 °C and 320 °C, which were related to the desorption of ammonia adsorbed on weak and medium acid sites, respectively. Upon desilication process in alkaline solution, the high-temperature peak intensity became weaken, and the low-temperature peak intensity enhanced simultaneously. It indicated the removal of Si species from USY framework changed the distribution of acidic sites. As to the USY@MSA sample, the high-temperature peak slightly shifted to 304 °C, implying the reduction of medium-acidic sites. Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra was generally employed to clarify the acidic properties. As shown in Fig. 9B, the stretching bands at 1545 cm−1 and 1454 cm−1 were assigned to the pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively, and the band at 1490 cm−1 was attributed to both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [43,44]. Pristine USY zeolite exhibited strong band at 1545 cm−1 and weak band at 1454 cm−1, indicating the Brønsted acid sites predominated the total acidity. Suffering from desilication treatment, the Brønsted acidity significantly decreased and the Lewis acidity slightly increased, due to the leaching out of Si specie from framework. In addition, a weak shoulder peak appeared at 1447 cm−1 corresponding to pyridine interacting with hydrogen band on the external surface. After self-assembly process, the band related to Brønsted acid sites kept almost intact and the band assigned to Lewis acid sites further enhanced, which was probably attributed to the insertion of extra-framework Al specie into USY framework. The increased intensity of the peak at 1447 cm−1 was correlated to the formation of abundant silicon hydroxyls within the mesoporous MSA shell. Accordingly, the USY@MSA sample demonstrated the increase acidity upon self-assembly process. 3.2 Hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane over different catalysts To construct the bifunctional catalyst for hydro-isomerization of n-hexadecane (n-C16), we then loaded 0.5 wt% Pt on different zeolites by the incipient wetness method. TEM image of Pt/USY@MSA revealed that the supported Pt nanoparticles mainly located on the mesoporous shell, which were highly dispersed with the average size of ca. 5 nm ( Fig. 10). In contrast, the supported Pt nanoparticles on the pristine USY zeolite and USY-dsAT0.1-PI0.1 mainly distributed on the surface of bulk crystal phase, giving an aggregated and heterogeneous distribution (Fig. S5). Moreover, the Pt dispersion of Pt/USY, Pt/USY-ds and Pt/USY@MSA samples were 30%, 31%, and 35%, respectively. It indicates the fabrication of mesoporous shell benefited to the confining effect and improvement of Pt dispersion. Firstly, the evolution of n-C16 conversion as a function of temperature for different catalysts were depicted ( Fig. 11A). With the increase in reaction temperature, the n-C16 conversion for all the catalysts increased apparently. Compared to Pt/USY catalyst, the Pt/USY-ds and the core-shell Pt/USY@MSA catalysts required a higher reaction temperature to reach equivalent conversion, indicating the relative low activity for the treated samples. According to previous reports, hydroconversion of alkane including hydroisomerization and cracking reaction proceeds mainly on Brønsted acid sites [45]. Accordingly, the considerable reduction of Brønsted acid sites upon desilication treatment led to the decline of hydromerization activity (Fig. 9). The Pt/USY-ds catalyst possessing the minimum amount of Brønsted acid sites exhibited the lowest activity for n-C16 hydroisomerization. While Pt/USY@MSA catalyst possessing more strong Brønsted acid sites was endowed with the boosted activity than the desilication catalyst. Fig. 11B depicts the curves of isomerized i-C16 yields versus conversion over different catalysts. All of the i-C16 yields showed a volcanic variation trend with the increase of n-C16 conversion. The maximum i-C16 yields for the Pt/USY and Pt/USY-ds catalysts were only 36.3% and 46.8%, respectively, which were obtained at the n-C16 conversion of 62.4% and 83.1%. It is noteworthy that Pt/USY@MSA catalyst exhibited the highest i-C16 yield of 61% at the conversion of 72.2%. Afterwards, all the branched isomer yields decreased sharply with the further increase of n-C16 conversion. High conversion was obtained at elevated temperatures, which led to serious cracking reaction especially for those with abundant Brønsted acid sites. Hence the branched isomers yield was extremely low at high conversion for Pt/USY and Pt/USY@MSA catalysts. The products distribution as a function of n-C16 conversion over Pt/USY, Pt/USY-ds and Pt/USY@MSA catalysts were depicted in Fig. S6. The Pt/USY catalyst achieved much higher selectivity of cracked products, compared to the Pt/USY-ds and Pt/USY@MSA catalysts. As for the Pt/USY@MSA catalyst, high selectivity to mono-branched was achieved at low n-C16 conversion (<40%) and high selectivity of multi-branched isomers was obtained at relatively high n-C16 conversion (40%∼85%). According to the classical metal-acid bifunctional mechanism, the hydroisomerization reactions of n-alkanes mainly comprises three processes: 1) the dehydrogenation of n-alkanes to n-alkene intermediates over metal sites, 2) isomerization of n-alkene intermediates to iso-alkenes over acid sites via carbenium ion mechanism, 3) hydrogenation of iso-alkenes over metal sites to form iso-alkanes ( Scheme 1). Amongst the isomerization of n-alkene is much slower than the dehydrogenation/hydrogenation steps, which is considered as the rate-determining step [46]. Meanwhile, the protonation alkene intermediates resting on acid sites may undergo C-C bond cracking side reaction and reduce the branched isomers yield. In this sense, the ideal hydroisomerization process requires fast diffusion of alkene intermediates within acidic zeolites, which could effectively inhibit the cracking reaction and promote isomerization reaction. Firstly, the USY@MSA sample exhibited the largest proportion of mesoporous volume than the desilicated Pt/USY-ds and conventional Pt/USY sample (76% vs 73% vs 56%). The interconnected porosities characteristic of Pt/USY@MSA catalysts significantly enhance the diffusion of alkene intermediates. Secondly, the distance between metal active sites and acid sites was found to play an essential role in the product distributions [1,26]. The nano-scale metal-acid distance is more beneficial for the formation of branched isomers, while the adjacent or millimetric scale metal-acid distance would cause serious cracking reaction or reduce the catalytic performance [26]. As to the Pt/USY-ds zeolite, although Pt particles mainly located on the outer surface, their location was still in close proximity to the acidic sites of USY of distance. The n-alkene intermediates were formed rapidly, while the isomerization of n-alkene intermediates was much slow. It is deduced that the newly formed n-alkene intermediates easily diffused to adjacent acidic sites and cracked into light hydrocarbons. With respect to Pt/USY@MSA catalyst, the mesoporous SiO2 acting as a wall to separate the acidic and metal sites. The confinement of the mesopores may lead to a longer residence of the n-alkene intermediates, but the mesoporous SiO2 has rare acidity and does not cause the cracking of n-alkene intermediates. Finally, the n-alkene intermediates diffused into the acidic sites of USY zeolites and isomerized to the i-alkene intermediates, resulting in the higher yield of branched isomers. According to characterizations, Pt particles within Pt/USY and Pt/USY-ds catalysts were trapped in the USY support, which may increase the residence time of the newly-formed alkene intermediates on acidic support and improve the probability of cracking side reactions. 4 Conclusions A Hierarchical core-shell USY@MSA material composing of desilicated USY core and Al-containing mesoporous silica shell was constructed via a self-assembly strategy without the addition of additional silicon source. The pristine USY zeolite couldn’t bear the harsh treatment with NaOH only, and piperidine acting as a structure-protecting agent effectively shielded the topology structure from collapse. The core-shell USY@MSA material was feathered with the interconnected channel structure and gradient acidity distribution. Due to the construction of hierarchical core-shell structure, highly dispersed Pt particles selectively deposited on mesoporous shell, generating nanoscale distance with the acid sites of USY support. The combination effect of hierarchical structure and favorable metal-acid balance effectively suppressed the cracking side reaction to a large extent and boosted the isomerization reaction. This result provides useful reference for the design of bifunctional catalysts for long-chain alkanes hydroisomerization process. coredata.dc:description: Hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes is an indispensable process in the upgrading of fuel oil and lubricants to meet the state of art regulations. In this work, a novel core-shell structural material comprising USY zeolite core and mesoporous aluminosilicate (MSA) shell, denoted as USY@MSA, was fabricated by virtue of a desilication and recrystallization approach. Comprehensive characterizations demonstrate that the USY@MSA composite exhibits a hierarchical pore architecture and a gradient acidity. Due to the confinement effect of the mesoporous aluminosilicate shell, highly dispersed platinum particles were selectively deposited on the shell, generating a nanoscale distance with acidic sites of USY zeolite core. In the hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane, the Pt/USY@MSA composite catalyst outperforms the conventional Pt/USY and desilicated Pt/USY-ds catalysts, effectively suppressing the cracking side reactions and producing higher selectivity to branched isomers.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of hierarchical core-shell Pt/USY@MSA bifunctional catalysts for hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane
